#Text=Of course, they will sell it as being high-tech and “best performance” but usually it’s a stripped-down caching solution that’s built for resource-efficiency rather than aggressive performance.
#Text=If you try to use an outside plugin, it simply won’t work or the webhosting company will automatically disable it.

#Text=Caching is usually faster and more resource-efficient from the server rather than through software-level PHP caching.If using LiteSpeed server, you can use built-in LiteSpeed server caching.If using NGINX server, you can use built-in FastCGI server caching.If using Apache (which you shouldn’t), you can use Varnish proxy or even NGINX proxy.All web-servers can use any software-level php caching (via cache plugin).

#Text=But some plugins are designed more for Apache/LiteSpeed servers, others for NGINX servers.Careful of certain webhosts (especially “managed webhosts”) who force you to use their caching solutions and won’t let you use other cache plugins.
#Text=Just know that the webserver or webhosting company you choose will affect your caching experience and what caching plugins you can use.
#Text=58.
#Text=Choosing the right cache plugins (BEG-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=I’ve tried over 50 different cache plugins.
#Text=The best ones have useful features, easy-to-use, and don’t break your site.
#Text=If you manage only a few sites, you might prefer aggressive plugins with many optimizations and even Facebook groups where people share tricks.
#Text=If you manage dozens of clients, you’ll prefer a safer plugin with less features and less chance of issues.
#Text=Best all-around cache plugins (allowed on any webserver) are Swift Performance or WP Rocket.
#Text=Swift more aggressive, Rocket more stable.There are other good cache plugins as well (WP Fastest Cache, Breeze, WP Performance, Comet Cache, Borlabs).W3TC sucks and very difficult to configure.
#Text=Don’t use unless you’re a pro.If using LiteSpeed server, you can use LiteSpeed Cache plugin.
#Text=My favorite.If using NGINX server, you can stick with NGINX helper plugins to keep it simple or a full-featured cache plugin like (Swift or WP Rocket).Do not combine multiple cache plugins!
#Text=I don’t like combining cache plugins with other performance plugins either, but it can work if configured carefully (and not overlapping functions).
#Text=Deciding which cache plugin to use depends on your use case.
#Text=Small site with 400 pages and little traffic?
#Text=– Swift or WP Rocket, with precaching enabled.Medium site with 400-1k pages, and medium traffic?
#Text=– Can go with cache plugin Swift/Rocket or server caching LiteSpeed/NGINX.
#Text=Both have pros and cons.Big site with 1k or more pages and lots of traffic?
#Text=– I like custom-configured LiteSpeed Cache or native-NGINX cache and no precaching necessary since you have so much traffic.
#Text=59.
#Text=Cache plugin configuration (INT-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Cache plugins are more complicated than ever to configure now since they do so many more things than just caching.
#Text=This section covers specifically only caching-related settings.
#Text=Regarding other options you see in cache plugin settings, my recommendation will be in other parts of this guide.
#Text=Rewrites vs PHP – most cache plugins only give you the PHP option.
#Text=If you have the option to use the rewrite method, try that as it’s faster.
#Text=If it causes problems, then switch to php method.Cache TTL – this means how long the cache should last for.
#Text=You should set this about as long as your content update intervals.
#Text=If you update every day, then set 24 hours.

#Text=If you almost never update, can make it 1 month.Private cache or logged-in users/pages – don’t use unless you really have that many logged-in users and you know how to prevent cache from mixing up content between users.Separate mobile cache – don’t use unless you have AMP or a specific design or content that only shows up on mobile.
#Text=Just because you have a mobile-responsive site doesn’t mean you need this.Caching 404 pages – yes if you have many users hitting them.

#Text=Better if you redirect all of them to actual pages.Dynamic cache – great for caching urls with queries or filters, like searches or ecommerce product filters.Exclude – absolutely critical for excluding pages that shouldn’t be cached.
#Text=I typically exclude checkout, logged-in user pages, or pages with forms.Browser cache – yes, enable it.Heartbeat control – I usually disable for all pages except posts.
#Text=Or if you need it on, you can increase its interval to every 120 seconds.
#Text=Not every caching setup or cache plugin will allow you to configure all those options.
#Text=Don’t freak out if you don’t see them.
#Text=In fact, there are so many possible settings…plese refer to my cache configuration guides below:
#Text=Swift Performance cache setup guideWP Rocket cache setup guideLiteSpeed cache setup guideFor all other cache plugins, I think you can follow my guides above to get a general idea.
#Text=60.
#Text=Configuring cache-prebuild (INT, MED-HIGH)
#Text=One of the most overlooked aspects of caching for me is the cache-prebuild process.
#Text=Some plugins call it “cache-preload”, others call it “cache-warming” or “cache-crawler”.
#Text=The cache-prebuild function is a mechanism that pre-caches pages so they load quickly when visited.
#Text=Back in the old days, caching was only used on high traffic sites and so no cache-preload was necessary.
#Text=The cache was built by the first visitor and all subsequent visitors benefitted from an already-built cache.
#Text=This was fine since you had thousands of visits and only the very first person was unlucky to see a “slower” page.
#Text=But in today’s caching era, letting the “first person warm your cache” is a terrible idea if you have very little traffic.
#Text=On a not-so-busy site with no cache prebuild, it might seem like all your visitors hit a cold (uncached) page.
#Text=FYI: users hitting cold cache will see a slower page load than without any caching at all!
#Text=So anyway, we have cache-prebuilding now.
#Text=There are very few servers that have or allow a server-wide cache prebuild function.
#Text=They’re probably afraid of users abusing it.
#Text=It’s in the same logic that many webhosts won’t allow you to use those broken-link checker plugins (because it eats up precious resources).
#Text=LiteSpeed servers have a built-in cache crawl function.
#Text=Few webhosts allow it on shared servers though.

#Text=You’ll probably only get access if you have it on your own VPS.Anybody not on LiteSpeed….well, there are many server-level cache warming mechanism and scripts out there but not quite so user-friendly.
#Text=You can search them out if you insist.
#Text=It’s much easier if you’re on LiteSpeed, though.The best server caching script I found is OCP.

#Text=Read my OCP guide.The only option (for most people) is to use a cache plugin that has cache prebuild functions built-in like Swift Performance and now WP Rocket (which copied that idea from Swift).Prebuilding improves the caching experience on your site by a whole lot.
#Text=Enable it if you can!
#Text=There are a few instances where you SHOULD NOT use cache-prebuild.
#Text=One is if you have many visitors, it’s useless since there’s already live traffic warming the cache.
#Text=The other is when you have too many pages.
#Text=I would say 1k pages is the general threshold.
#Text=If you have over 1k pages and you update your site often, I recommend NOT pre-caching since your server will use many resources and never even finish the job.
#Text=If your cache gets purged before it ever finishes, it’s stuck in a perpetual cycle of constantly prebuilding cache that’s never used.
#Text=61.
#Text=Object caching configuration (BEG-INT, MED-HIGH)
#Text=Object caching is useful for dynamic sites (constantly-refreshed data and/or can’t be cached) or any sites with lots of calculated numbers/reports in admin backend.
#Text=Object caching saves the database calls in RAM so they don’t have to be looked up every time they’re queried.
#Text=Because RAM is precious (less abundant than hard drive space and necessary for running programs), object caching is not usually allowed on many shared hosting plans.
#Text=Also it has to be enabled through the server…so it’s only possible if you have your own server or on a hosting plan that allows object caching.
#Text=Object caching must be enabled from the server.Object caching can be managed through the webhosting control panel or WordPress plugin.
#Text=(Plugin is better.)It’s best if you have a cache plugin that manages both page caching and object caching (like LiteSpeed Cache).
#Text=This way, they purge cache at the same time.You can use an object cache expiry time of 5 to 10 minutes to be safe.
#Text=But if your content isn’t update often, you can go higher like up to 30-60 minutes.
#Text=I recommend not to use object caching if you have just a static site.
#Text=In some cases, it’s even slower than just plain page-caching.
#Text=Enabling it “just in case” does not help!
#Text=Of course, you can test and see for yourself.
#Text=Top reasons to use object cache:
#Text=Slow admin backend.Slow database-heavy functions.Don’t know if your pages are suffering from slow query?
#Text=Check with Query Monitor.
#Text=62.
#Text=Browser cache aka “htaccess expires headers” (BEG, LOW)

#Text=This is that common tactic where people paste a bunch of lines into their htaccess so static files are browser-cached for a long time (1 week, 1 month, or even a year) so users don’t have re-download them again.
#Text=Maybe it was a big deal before…well it isn’t anymore.

#Text=Many devices (like mobile) have limited space and delete their browser cache when they want, not when you want.Browser cache only helps for returning visitors, and many sites don’t have much repeat traffic anyway.

#Text=(Besides, it’s the new visitors that we care more about improving user experience.)If you want to use browser cache, it’s more conveniently done through a cache plugin…rather than copy-pasting long commands into your htaccess file.
#Text=63.
#Text=Ignore query strings on page caching (BEG, MED)
#Text=Query strings are (the extra text at the end of urls) used to send information to the server.
#Text=Examples of query strings below and what they do:
#Text=search – show different search results.
#Text=(e.g. search?
#Text==wordpress+tips)ref – lets the site track who referred the user and save info within conversion tracking software.
#Text=(e.g. ref?
#Text==affiliateID)fbclid – lets the site know the user came from Facebook.
#Text=(e.g. fbclid=123ABC)(product) filter – show different products based on name, price, size or other product specifications.
#Text=(e.g. filter_size?
#Text==large)
#Text=As you can see, some of these query strings actually alter the page content whereas other strings show the same page content regardless of the query string.
#Text=The idea here is to exclude the query strings (that don’t change content) from caching so your cache mechanism doesn’t store those hits as a different page.
#Text=This would save your server from unnecessary work recaching the same page under a different url string AND serve the page faster to visitors from existing cache.
#Text=This makes a big difference for visitors coming in from query string urls such as Facebook ads, affiliate links, email newsletter links (with conversion-tracking).
#Text=Here’s how you IGNORE Query Strings when Caching.
#Text=64.
#Text=Private caching for logged-in users (ADV, MED)
#Text=Private caching is rarely practiced as most sites don’t need it (they don’t have many logged-in users).
#Text=Caching public pages is easy since everyone sees the same page.
#Text=Caching private pages is hard because of having to cache how each user sees the page differently AND (preferably) not wasting so much space resaving mostly similar pages over and over in cache.

#Text=Some private pages are easy – same content for all logged-in users, but something else for users not logged in.Some private pages are harder – shows mostly same content but also custom data depending on the user (like their name/username).Other private pages are tricky – shows completely different content to each user.
#Text=The easiest way to deal with private pages is to use object caching instead of page caching.
#Text=To be more aggressive, you can carefully enable private caching…BUT make sure users can’t see each others info and the public can’t see private content.
#Text=There are certain mechanisms out there like LiteSpeed’s ESI feature where you can show different content and widgets depending on the users…which is nice.
#Text=But ultimately at this level, you need to either hire a pro or spend lots of time to configure something that not only works but also doesn’t eat up so much resources (memory and space).
#Text=Private caching is tough!
#Text=65.
#Text=HTML-caching at the edge (INT, MED)
#Text=This is a relatively new technology for WordPress.
#Text=There are several plugins and services out there that can cache your pages at the edge and use CDN mirrors to serve them to clients around the world.
#Text=There are 3 main benefits:
#Text=Caching done on their server, not yours – reduces your server load, helps slow webhosting, decrease server costs, allow caching even if server doesn’t have it.
#Text=Basically…allows you fast speeds even if your webhosting/server sucks!
#Text=HTML delivered from CDN – traditionally, CDN’s only transfer static assets like images and CSS/JS.

#Text=With this new edge-caching for HTML, they can serve the HTML from the nearby pop server as well…theoretically improving page load for visitors far from your origin server.Further DDOS protection – since less of your server is used, less of your server is exposed to DDOS attacks.
#Text=Notable edge-caching plugins and services available:
#Text=QUIC.cloud – from the makers of LiteSpeed webservers.
#Text=Their Q.C service allows any website to benefit from LiteSpeed quickness even if they don’t have LiteSpeed servers.Shifter – sold as a “static site generator for WordPress”.
#Text=Seems to be a very different user experience from the usual WordPress workflow.WP Cloudflare Super Page Cache – allows you to cache everything with the free Cloudflare plan.
#Text=Something previous plugins have claimed to do but fail in one way or another.I believe there are some more but I can’t find them now.
#Text=Do you need these services, or are they beneficial if you already have a fast server?
#Text=I think not so much.
#Text=I don’t use any of them as I’m happy with my server caching already.
#Text=But these can be great options for those on weaker servers.
#Text=Keep an eye on this segment as I’m sure it will evolve quickly.
#Text=7.
#Text=Local asset optimization
#Text=Assets are any static files loading from your server.
#Text=CSS stylesheets, JS scripts, images, fonts, videos.
#Text=They need to be processed quickly because they often ARE the content OR they directly affect how the content is shown.
#Text=Simply put, your content cannot load until your assets are loaded!
#Text=Now the trick is in how we load the assets.
#Text=Some should load first, others should load later.
#Text=Stuff that’s visual and near the top of the page should be prioritized.
#Text=What we don’t want is less-important assets to block the critical ones.
#Text=How else can we optimize the way they load?
#Text=66.
#Text=Reduce asset requests.
#Text=(BEG-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=The fastest request is the one not made!
#Text=And the most obvious way to reduce asset requests (and overall HTML) is not to call them in the first place.
#Text=Many people spend so much time trying to compress and combine junk that shouldn’t have even been there in the first place!
#Text=Please reconsider everything you have on your page.
#Text=Get rid of stuff you don’t need.
#Text=(Plugins, images, fonts, etc.)Get rid of visual effects you don’t need.
#Text=(Animations, mouseovers, etc.)Disable unnecessary plugin CSS/JS.Consider moving things to other pages.
#Text=Don’t put your entire site on the homepage.The less stuff you have loaded, the fewer assets needed.
#Text=And for the assets you still have?
#Text=We have more tricks…
#Text=67.
#Text=Remove unused WordPress core JS (BEG, LOW)
#Text=WordPress by default includes a couple javascripts that might not be used.
#Text=You can disable them with some simple snippets in your functions.php file.
#Text=wp-embed.js – conveniently embed Youtube videos or unfurl links in the editor and content.
#Text=If you literally never embed videos and all your content is just text and images, you can dequeue it.wp-emoji-release.js – little JS that turns punctuation marks into emojis.
#Text=You can disable this since modern browsers already support emojis natively.jquery-migrate.min.js – supports older WordPress themes and plugins still running on the old jquery library.
#Text=Sites using updated themes/plugins can safely disable this.jquery.js – largish JS library used by many themes/plugins.
#Text=It’s convenient since themes/plugins won’t load extra JS if they can use the default jquery JS.
#Text=The issue is some themes/plugins DON’T use it and they load their own JS anyway.
#Text=Disable if your theme/plugins don’t use it.
#Text=If you don’t know, then disable and check everything carefully…or consult the documentation for every theme/plugin that you installed.
#Text=I’m sure you’ve seen some performance plugins that offer to disable these for you.
#Text=I suggest not using them as they sometimes create their own extra load.
#Text=I prefer disabling these manually in functions.php OR using the built-in functions in my caching plugin.
#Text=68.
#Text=Use native CSS/JS optimizations from your theme & plugins (BEG, MED)
#Text=If your theme or plugin has built-in CSS/JS optimization features, use them as they are safer and likely won’t cause any issues.

#Text=Theme or pagebuilders allowing CSS/JS merge and minification – use it.Plugins allowing different CSS generation options – always pick “external CSS file”, as it’s faster and safer than putting them “inline” or in “database”.
#Text=Only use inline if it’s super tiny CSS (like 3 lines).
#Text=69.
#Text=Combine CSS/JS for small sites only!
#Text=(BEG, LOW)
#Text=There is a huge debate whether you should combine and minify your CSS/JS, aka “concatenation”.
#Text=I believe it’s better (in general) if you don’t combine CSS/JS .
#Text=With that said, smaller sites can benefit from combining since most of the load time for tiny CSS/JS will come from the DNS lookup rather than the code processing.
#Text=As for larger sites or larger CSS files, I definitely recommend not combining them.
#Text=You can read the link above for my explanation why.
#Text=Basically, it’s because HTTP/2 makes concatenation unnecessary and also that not all CSS/JS should load in one file.
#Text=If you plan to combine CSS/JS, it’s best IMO to do it only through your theme CSS options.
#Text=(Of course, it only combines theme-related CSS and not plugins.)
#Text=70.
#Text=Combining CSS/JS for big sites (ADV, MED)
#Text=I already said why not to combine CSS/JS, and I still stand by that.
#Text=But I know some people are going to insist on it anyway because they care more about page scores or what other people on the internet said…fine, do it like this:
#Text=EASY – use the CSS/JS combine options in your cache plugin.
#Text=Test your site.
#Text=If some styling or functions break, then exclude the problematic ones.ADVANCED – use a specialized CSS/JS combination plugin (Autoptimize is the best) alongside a cache plugin.
#Text=This method requires more configuration but gives you more granular control over the optimizations and takes load off your caching mechanism.
#Text=Can actually be nice since content changes won’t purge your CSS/JS.NOTE: don’t use the combination features in your cache plugin if you’re doing it with another plugin.
#Text=Duh!
#Text=NOTE #2: if your theme/pagebuilder has combine options as well…yes, you can use them all together.
#Text=But combine the pagebuilder and plugins first and then do it overall from your cache plugin.
#Text=What to do when styling or functions break (which will happen for 95% of you).
#Text=Disable the optimizations and re-enable one at a time – test each change.
#Text=Do one with just CSS, then another with just JS.
#Text=Sometimes, it’s only one CSS or JS that’s causing the problem.
#Text=Find out which one it is and exclude it from combining:
#Text=Isolation Method #1 – with combine CSS/JS on, open your site in Chrome > Developer Tools > Network (tab), and reload the page.
#Text=Click the little red error circle to see which CSS/JS are missing.
#Text=Exclude them and see if things work.Isolation Method #2 – disable combine (and also caching), and scan your site in Pingdom.
#Text=Sort the waterfall items by file-type (neatly displaying all CSS/JS).
#Text=Now re-enable combine but manually exclude whichever CSS/JS you think is causing the issue.
#Text=HINT: whatever’s breaking is probably related to the problem.
#Text=Did a certain plugin or theme function stop working?
#Text=Try disabling those CSS/JS.
#Text=Yes, it takes a lot of trial and error.
#Text=It could be anywhere; maybe a plugin, maybe your theme.TIP: sick of trying to isolate the issue?
#Text=How about combining only the CSS/JS for the single most bloated extension?
#Text=For most people, this is either the theme or pagebuilder.
#Text=So combine all the assets for one thing and exclude everything else.
#Text=It’s an easy way to get most of the benefit you’re looking for without the combine conflict issues.
#Text=What if you’re still having issues?
#Text=What if your site seems fast but has a small FOIT or FOUT issue?
#Text=What if your site feels even slower?
#Text=This is why I told you not to do it!
#Text=71.
#Text=Manually combine custom CSS (INT-ADV, LOW)

#Text=Another clever way of reducing unnecessary CSS requests is to disable all custom CSS enqueued by plugins and manually adding them to your theme custom CSS area.Yes…if you’re combining all CSS into your theme custom CSS, you probably won’t need those “Add custom CSS” plugins anymore.
#Text=Get rid of them.
#Text=If you’re lucky, some plugins have an easy checkbox to disable their CSS styling.
#Text=Others you can only dequeue the CSS with filter code snippet placed into your functions.php.
#Text=For plugins that don’t allow either, you can manually edit out the CSS call from the plugin (but you’ll have to re-do these hacks if you update the plugin).
#Text=72.
#Text=Remove unused CSS styles (ADV, MED)
#Text=You can lighten your CSS by removing all unused styles.
#Text=Simply go into your theme or plugin CSS and delete anything not used.
#Text=It’s common to have themes and plugins with redundant/unnecessary styling for the same elements.
#Text=Probably helps to make screenshots of your site page templates in desktop and mobile before you edit.
#Text=Unused sections.Unused blocks or elements.Unused buttons or icons.Unused tables.Unused typography.
#Text=One thing to note is that if you’re removing from your theme or plugins default CSS, they might come back if you update your theme/plugin later.
#Text=Wishing for a methodical process?
#Text=The Tale of Removing Unused CSS from WordPress (WP Speed Matters) – a great guide written by another respected WP speed addict.
#Text=He also mentions all the tools I would have listed.Check all site templates on frontend.
#Text=See which scripts they load.
#Text=See which parts are obviously unused.
#Text=Usually, there are many design elements of the theme/plugin that you never use.
#Text=Start commenting styles out and then fully delete after a month if your site has no issues.
#Text=Or make a backup and delete on the spot, up to you.
#Text=73.
#Text=Remove unused JS scripts (ADV, MED)
#Text=Good luck trying to do this.
#Text=It’s damn near impossible unless this JS was custom-written by you.
#Text=The reason why many sites load unused JS is because it’s loading JS for all the features available in your themes/plugins (yes, even the ones you don’t use).
#Text=So sure, you can try to remove them manually but that means your theme or plugins might break if you change their settings or options later.
#Text=There really isn’t any way except to do a code-refactor and how the heck are you going to do that?
#Text=That’s the theme or plugin developer’s job.
#Text=What we can do is perhaps diagnose your site and see how much unused JS there is.
#Text=And with that, you can find where the bloat is in your theme and plugins and which ones to replace.
#Text=Find Unused JavaScript And CSS Code With The Coverage Tab In Chrome DevTools – Google Tools for Developers
#Text=74.
#Text=Manually refactor CSS/JS (ADV, LOW-MED)
#Text=If you got the skills, you can take it a step further by rewriting your entire CSS from scratch.
#Text=Carefully cleaning and reorganizing the styles to make it easier to read and lighter to parse.
#Text=In moments like this, you can even rethink your design to make things simpler.
#Text=75.
#Text=Javascript async and defer (ADV, MED)
#Text=There’s a lot of talk behind JS async/defer tactics, but they aren’t always used for good reason.
#Text=And it doesn’t help when annoying page tests make generic recommendations for users who don’t know how JS works.
#Text=Not all javascript should be async or deferred!

#Text=Any JS used for ATF items should be left alone.Any JS not used for critical elements should be deferred if you don’t need their functionality immediately.JS async can be used as long as you test first.
#Text=The problem with speed tests is that they try to improve page scores at all costs.
#Text=They don’t know what your JS is specifically used for so they make silly blanket suggestions that might actually hurt your page load!
#Text=Deferring JS will delay the visible effects or functions reliant on them!
#Text=AJAX (autofill) search functions – defer is ok.Conversion tracking – do you want to start tracking sooner or later?
#Text=(I like later.)Chatbox – for sales/support.
#Text=Deferring makes sense.Content-rendering – do you have special pages or content relying on JS?
#Text=If that specific content is important or near the top of page, don’t defer.Link plugins – do you have specific JS for rendering affiliate links?
#Text=I think defer is ok.Pop-ups – defer is better.Security functions – any JS that applies captcha or prevents right-clicking, or any other security.
#Text=I think deferring is ok.Sliders or image animation – terrible idea if they’re at the top of your site!
#Text=They’ll load slower if deferred!
#Text=(Probably a good rule never to defer visible elements near the top of your page.)
#Text=What’s even funnier for me is that you could just manually “defer” things yourself by putting the code in the footer instead of the header.
#Text=Things like Google Analytics can be placed later and it will load later (after all HTML has been parsed).
#Text=So if you really think about it, the only reason people use JS async/defer is to optimize the load for any JS automatically placed in the header.
#Text=And if it’s placed there, don’t you think it probably means it should be loaded earlier???
#Text=So like I said, be careful what you async/defer!
#Text=If you wanna play with it, test carefully.
#Text=But in general, I prefer to leave them untouched to be safe.
#Text=There’s no point in scoring higher on a page test but your certain site elements or functions loads slower.
#Text=JS makes little impact on well-coded sites.
#Text=76.
#Text=How to minify HTML, CSS, JS (BEG, LOW)
#Text=Code minification decreases file sizes by removing all spaces and unnecessary code comments.
#Text=This results in fewer bytes sent through the internet without any loss of function.
#Text=It’s a win-win all around!

#Text=Small sites don’t have much to benefit from minification.Larger sites will benefit more (especially for slower mobile visitors), but even then minification doesn’t help much once your CSS/JS is browser-cached anyway!
#Text=My only issue is with how this code is minified.
#Text=Through a cache plugin – ok for small sites.Through specific CSS/JS optimization plugin (Autoptimize) – better option for large sites.Through a CDN – best and easiest method, IMO.
#Text=Most people do it through a plugin, either cache plugin or one of those “performance plugins” (Autoptimize) that specialize in combining and minifying your CSS/JS.
#Text=The cache plugin is most convenient and works fine for all sites.
#Text=But if your site is big with many pages, and/or lots of traffic…you’ll get better results with a dedicated CSS/JS optimization plugin.

#Text=They have more feature, more control, and best of all…they save you a lot of server load when you purge cache (since your cache plugin doesn’t have to rebuild CSS/JS when page cache is rebuilt).
#Text=The extra load on cache prebuild is bad if you have a big site (and minifying with cache plugin).
#Text=Every time cache purges, it completely rebuilds all pages and CSS/JS.
#Text=It’s fast on a 10-20 page site but awful if you have many pages and different page layouts.The extra load can also be bad if you have low traffic (and no cache prebuild).
#Text=Since uncached visits will take longer to load (thanks to the extra task of minification).
#Text=The easiest way to minify is enable it from your CDN (so it processes on their severs) instead of slowing down your web server.
#Text=I only enable minification from Cloudflare.
#Text=I don’t use it from any plugins.Enabling it is easy.
#Text=Just check the boxes.
#Text=77.
#Text=Lazy loading images (INT, LOW)
#Text=I hate lazyload as a general tactic.
#Text=It makes your site appear faster to page tests, but loads images slower for human visitors.
#Text=This is terrible UX!
#Text=If you’re going to use it, you have to know which things should be lazy loaded and which things should not.

#Text=It is SAFE to lazy load images below the fold but NOT if your site has many fast-scroll users (like shopping sites).It is NOT RECOMMENDED to lazy load any images at the top of the site (header, banner) obviously since that makes them appear slower to visitors.It is NOT NECESSARY to lazy load images if you don’t have many or if they’re small.
#Text=In optimizing many sites every week, I can assure you that 99% of them would look faster without lazy load.
#Text=It sucks that most sites can’t control which images lazy load or not.
#Text=Currently, it’s either an ON or OFF setting in cache plugins.
#Text=No granular access.
#Text=Native lazy load is available in recent browsers through attributes to specify “lazy” (on) or “eager” (off) or “auto” (browser determines).
#Text=But if you want to make it easy on yourself, I suggest not lazy-loading.
#Text=So lazy loading doesn’t speed up page load?
#Text=– nope!
#Text=It delays it.
#Text=Your site only gets higher page scores because those don’t trigger your images to load like real visitors will.But doesn’t lazy loading decrease bandwidth use?
#Text=– yes but that’s not much benefit unless your images are huge or you have that many of them.Doesn’t lazy loading help by loading fewer things?
#Text=– it doesn’t load fewer.
#Text=It loads the same but delays them.
#Text=If your user doesn’t scroll, it helps.
#Text=If your user scrolls, it hurts.
#Text=78.
#Text=Conditional CSS/JS asset loaders (ADV, LOW-MED)
#Text=There are several plugins out there (usually called “asset optimizers”, “asset organizers”, or “plugin organizers”) that can decide which pages will allow which CSS/JS to load.
#Text=Some organize by plugin, disabling PLUGIN activation on the pages you choose.
#Text=Others organize by CSS/JS, disabling CSS/JS load on the pages you choose.
#Text=They are a lot of work to configure and cause problems for your site if you’re not careful.
#Text=You also have to be careful which ones you choose.
#Text=Some are written well.
#Text=Others are terrible because their plugin adds its own load overhead, which defeats the purpose!
#Text=If you insist on messing with these, research them for yourself and good luck.
#Text=Don’t try to remove every little thing off every little page.
#Text=Focus on the heavier plugins and CSS/JS.Focus on your slower pages and more important pages (like Home or Cart/Checkout).I like WP Gonzalez and Asset CleanUp.
#Text=Generally, I recommend you not to use any of these plugins and to just pick lean plugins in the first place.
#Text=I don’t use these as I like to optimize manually.
#Text=79.
#Text=Deploying a CDN aka “content delivery network” (INT, MED)
#Text=Do you need a CDN?
#Text=If your traffic is local—NO!
#Text=Try Cloudflare for easiest free CDN.
#Text=(Great for beginners and many sites.)Want better performance than Cloudflare?
#Text=Try BunnyCDN (still low cost).Need CDN for large files?
#Text=Try S3 and Cloudfront!
#Text=Want a more aggressive “push CDN”?
#Text=Look it up!
#Text=Some CDNs cover certain geographical areas better than others.
#Text=Network latency time is a common area of slowdown in delivering static assets (images, css, js).
#Text=Faraway visitors have to wait 1-3 secs longer to receive requested assets.
#Text=But if you use a CDN service, the files load faster since they’ll come from a mirror server closer to the visitor.
#Text=That’s all a CDN service really is, a company with multiple mirror servers all over the world.
#Text=How they differ is in their pricing, features, and performance around the world.
#Text=If you don’t know what you’re doing, just get Cloudflare and be done with it.
#Text=It’s free and works well enough.
#Text=If you want to venture down the rabbit hole of CDN’s.
#Text=Just know that there are 2 kinds of CDN’s:
#Text=Pull CDN – the dominant method since it’s less hassle for users.
#Text=The first visitor loads the CDN (experiencing delayed page load) but all subsequent visitors get faster speeds.

#Text=Sites with low traffic may feel it’s not worth it, since CDN cache expires before next visitor arrives.Push CDN – higher performance since files are manually “pushed” to the CDN’s mirror servers by you or your CDN management plugin.
#Text=With push CDN’s, no visitors will ever experience a “slow CDN pull”.
#Text=Downside is it’s more management to push files and things can break or look incorrect if visitors reach a site CDN missing updated files.
#Text=Traditional CDN’s vs Cloudflare
#Text=Technically, Cloudflare is not a CDN but has CDN-like features.
#Text=It’s actually a DNS service.
#Text=You enable it by pointing your domain (from your registrar) to Cloudflare’s nameservers.

#Text=Then manage your DNS functions from Cloudflare, pointing it back to your webhost and enabling Cloudflare’s performance/security features.Traditional CDN’s work by supplying you with a domain zone (like “123yourdomain.maxcdn.com) where your assets are mirrored.
#Text=Then you configure your site to load all static assets from this zone.
#Text=You can also mask that CDN domain behind yours (like “cdn.yourdomain.com”).Both traditional CDN’s and Cloudflare can be managed by a CDN plugin on your site.
#Text=You can also manage them from your cache plugin (most convenient).
#Text=This way, your cache plugin purges both server cache and CDN cache at the same time.
#Text=80.
#Text=Cloudflare optimization (INT, LOW-MED)
#Text=There are many little optimizations you can do with Cloudflare aside from just enabling a CDN.
#Text=There are also some settings you shouldn’t touch (because they potentially break your site or hurt performance).
#Text=Please follow my guide:
#Text=Cloudflare settings guide (best performance)
#Text=Yes, I think you should use Cloudflare even if you don’t want their performance/security features.
#Text=You can use them only for DNS functions.
#Text=Their proxy is easily disabled from the DNS tab; just turn all the orange clouds to grey.
#Text=81.
#Text=Hosting videos locally vs externally (INT, HIGH)

#Text=Don’t host videos from your server (especially if you need them to load fast) OR you have high traffic or large videos.CDN can help serve locally-loaded videos.Video hosts (Youtube, Vimeo) can make external-hosting cheaper.S3 or Vimeo are great for hosting private videos.
#Text=If your video is auto-played on page load, you need the fastest load possible.
#Text=I don’t recommend loading them from your server since that can quickly run up bandwidth limits and slow down your server.
#Text=CDN – less technical work as your videos still sit on the server.

#Text=CDN will serve the video quickly worldwide, but can get expensive if you have big videos and/or lots of traffic.Free video hosting (Youtube, Vimeo) – low cost, integrates with video community, but loads slow external scripts.

#Text=You can get around the external scripts using iframe-lazyload but that won’t help for auto-play videos.Paid external hosting (S3+Cloudfront, Vimeo business) – costs money but gives you more control over how your videos look and also allows you to make them private, only viewable from your sites.
#Text=(Good for members-only content.)
#Text=Some services like Wistia, are really expensive but come with conversion-tracking features and other junk, hahaha.
#Text=Hosting videos elsewhere is always a great idea.
#Text=The only issue is making sure they load fast enough and don’t run up your bills.
#Text=Storing them in S3 is handy if you like having control and flexibility over the videos.
#Text=S3 is great for integrating with other software, like ecommerce or download management, but requires more technical work and can costs money.
#Text=S3 is good for video downloads and streaming, but can be slow for overseas users.
#Text=Therefore, you should always integrate S3 with Cloudfront CDN!
#Text=S3 and Cloudfront are both Amazon AWS, making them easy to integrate.
#Text=Vimeo paid plans are absolutely awesome; I love them, too.
#Text=Easy to generate featured images (using plugins), easy to put into your content (it just embeds).
#Text=Can control which domains it shows on.
#Text=Comes with nice video reports, counting views, other user tracking.
#Text=My last note is that if this video is on your home page right at the top…it’s probably worth testing different methods to see which one loads it the fastest.
#Text=Maybe from your server, maybe S3 + Cloudfront, maybe Youtube/Vimeo…who knows, test it!
#Text=All other non-essential videos, their slowdown is more because of the video player than the actual video itself.
#Text=And for those, I have more tactics. 🙂
#Text=82.
#Text=Hosting large files (INT, MED)
#Text=Just like with videos, you should not host large files on your server at all.
#Text=Even if they’re seldom accessed or downloaded.
#Text=Just one person downloading a 1gb file from your server is enough to slow down your regular web-traffic.
#Text=Also, it’s more sensible not to have giant files on the server when doing site backups (waste of space).
#Text=Use S3 to store the files.Combine it with Amazon’s Cloudfront CDN feature if you need faster download speeds to visitors around the world.Large files for me is anything above 50mb.
#Text=If you have just one 200mb that rarely gets downloaded, ok fine.
#Text=If you have a 1gb file or many 200mb files…probably not.Some servers are stronger than others, right?
#Text=83.
#Text=Managing a large media library (INT, MED)
#Text=Some sites have such a massive media library (tons of images) that it no longer fits on the web-server.
#Text=This is a performance issue because the web-servers disk is usually the fastest and most convenient place to retrieve website files.
#Text=Putting your images anywhere else is likely to be slower retrieval.
#Text=You have a few choices in moments like this, each with pros & cons:
#Text=Upgrade the server plan – easy way to get more space and better performance without changing your site much.
#Text=But costs more and still might not be enough space.Offload to S3 – using the fantastic WP Offload Media plugin.
#Text=It allows Cloudfront CDN integration, too!

#Text=I love this method but some people might not like the cost.Add block storage – theoretically fast enough for application-use and also affordable ($1/month per 10gb) but I feel like it’s messy and not all that flexible.
#Text=Sure you can mount it to just some directories or even the entire wp-uploads directory.ORRR you can just delete unused media sizes if you want to quickly shrink your library.
#Text=I’ve seen sites go from 100k to 10k images with no design changes!
#Text=Yes, there are alternative plugins that do what WP Offload Media does, but none of them with the same respect as its development team (Delicious Brains).
#Text=8.
#Text=External asset optimization
#Text=Optimizing external assets is very difficult if not impossible.
#Text=These are all the files that load from somewhere other than your web server (thus “external assets”).

#Text=This can be webfonts (Google fonts) or font icons (FontAwesome), images, JS scripts for Google Analytics, JS for conversion tracking (Facebook Pixel, Hotjar), JS script for affiliate (Amazon), JS library, JS script for Youtube (or Vimeo), embeds like Facebook box or Twitter, JS for social media share counts, and on and on and on.

#Text=The hardest part about this is that their servers aren’t always the fastest (no duh, a free service is not gonna dedicate all server resources to you) and their files aren’t always the lightest.
#Text=You may have seen complaints from page tests about them not being browser cached for long enough, or being too big, etc.
#Text=Whatever the case may be, you have little control over files that aren’t loaded on your server!
#Text=So what can we do?
#Text=Load them locally.Load them early (aka “prefetch”).Load them late (aka “defer”).
#Text=84.
#Text=Audit all external requests (INT, MED)
#Text=Do you even know what’s loading externally from other domains?
#Text=It’s funny but I see many clients unaware of all the external calls made from their site.
#Text=To check: open up your Developer Tools, click on “Sources” tab and load all your site pages.
#Text=Common (unexpected) external requests:
#Text=Absolute urls – to your own page.
#Text=Technically not an external request but try to use relative urls.

#Text=If you’re doing for outdated SEO tactics, stop it.Stock theme images – default images linked from the demo site (even when they exist on your site).Old conversion scripts (Hotjar, Pixel) – that you stopped using but forgot to remove from your theme files.Unnecessary crap – any images, CSS, JS scripts or libraries, loading for things you don’t even use.
#Text=85.
#Text=Load simple assets locally (INT, MED)
#Text=Anything simple enough for you to load locally, do it.
#Text=Images, CSS, JS…copy them to your site.
#Text=86.
#Text=Load webfonts locally (BEG-ADV, HIGH)
#Text=As I’ve already explained, you can load webfonts locally to reduce their speed impact.
#Text=Best if you can do it manually (and also to subset out unnecessary stuff).You can also use handy plugin like OMGF | Host Google Fonts Locally.Don’t use FontAwesome!
#Text=(use other ways to show icons)Btw, Swift Performance cache plugin has a cool Critical Font option to optimize for Font Awesome.
#Text=87.
#Text=Load Google Analytics locally (BEG, MED)
#Text=There are tons of hacks out there.
#Text=Some of them do excessive stuff like cutting down the JS file to the bare minimum or loading the GA script from public CDN (jsDelivr).
#Text=Other methods are tedious hacks liking copying the GA script to your server and running cron commands to keep it updated.
#Text=I think that’s fine for totally small sites without any conversion tracking.
#Text=But otherwise…keep it simple and use CAOS plugin (my favorite).

#Text=CAOS | Host Google Analytics Locally (my favorite and easiest method)How to Load Google Analytics 10x Faster in WordPress (WP Speed Matters) – fun guide fellow WP speed addict, Gijo Varghese.Flying Analytics plugin – built by Gijo to locally-load GA.
#Text=Has 3 useful settings depending on your GA use.
#Text=88.
#Text=Lazy loading videos (INT, HIGH)
#Text=You can use the “lazy load iframe” feature in your cache plugin.Do NOT lazy load any videos at the top of your homepage!
#Text=If you’re embedding videos through Youtube, Vimeo or other iframe, there are plugins that not only lazy load it but also have extra features:
#Text=Load only on user interaction – mouse move, scroll, or mobile touch.
#Text=Great idea!
#Text=Lazy load sensitivity – loads the iframe once the screen gets close.
#Text=Great idea!
#Text=Pseudo image – loads an IMAGE of the video player with fake play button, and only loads the real video if clicked.
#Text=Very clever!
#Text=(Usually only compatible with Youtube, some can do Vimeo as well.)
#Text=(Many of these can be found in Swift Performance.)
#Text=Even if you don’t have all those fancy features in your cache plugin, just being able to lazy load iframes alone is a huge difference.
#Text=Another way you can manually hack things is to show a fake image of the player which then opens up a lightbox modal with the video inside.
#Text=Anyway, I’m sure more native browser lazy load is soon to come.
#Text=Regarding best plugins to do the pseduo video image effect, I suggest you test on your own.
#Text=Try search the WP repo for “video lazy load“.If there’s any concern with lazy loading, I do wonder if it affects your SEO since crawlers don’t see the video loaded.
#Text=Who knows, right?
#Text=89.
#Text=Google Maps optimizations (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=Don’t be one of those newbies loading the Google Maps box right on your site!
#Text=It slows your site down by a lot!
#Text=Put an image of the map instead, then link to Google Maps from that image or from some text under it.Or use “lazy load iframes” option from cache plugin to delay the Google Map load.
#Text=90.
#Text=Social media integrations; Facebook, Twitter, Instagram (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=Have you ever wanted to show the Facebook like box right on your page?
#Text=Just don’t!
#Text=It lags like hell.
#Text=Will cost you a solid 1 second.
#Text=If you want, put it on a specific page but not your home page or global widget!
#Text=Same goes for Twitter box.
#Text=What about an Instagram stream?
#Text=For whatever reason, those have been less laggy for me.
#Text=I like the Social Feed Gallery by QuadLayers.What about Facebook Pixel?
#Text=Sorry guys, I don’t have any methods yet.
#Text=Unless these boxes are your main page content….trust me, you don’t need it.
#Text=It’s not worth the tremendous slowdown they cause, especially on mobile devices.
#Text=Still insist on having a social feed on your site?
#Text=Maybe this Social Feed Cloudflare app can help.
#Text=91.
#Text=Comments and Gravatar (INT, LOW-MED)
#Text=Comments are a problems most people don’t have…until their blogs get popular and there’s hundreds or thousands of comments.
#Text=In fact, even 100 comments on one post is enough to chip away at your page speed and start making your site less fun to visit.
#Text=We have a few concerns to look at and different ways of tackling them.
#Text=Which comment system to use?
#Text=And how they deal with 3rd-party assets.
#Text=The built-in WordPress comments system is fast and free but loads all at once.
#Text=This can be annoying if you don’t want all 500 comments (and their Gravatar) loading on one page.
#Text=It’s not only a speed issue but a design issue.
#Text=Of course, there are work-arounds.
#Text=You can limit how many comments are loaded.
#Text=Some people paginate comments.
#Text=On my busiest site, I put a button to [LOAD COMMENTS] on mobile, so users aren’t intimidated by a giant scrolling page on their phone.
#Text=You can also use alternative avatar systems, or cache your Gravatars (via cache plugin or specific Gravatar cache plugin).
#Text=Or not use any comment avatar at all!
#Text=I personally prefer native WordPress comment system.
#Text=Disqus is a 3rd-party commenting system that’s no longer free, but has lots of engagement features and looks nice (styled cleanly, and only loads recent comments).
#Text=The big con aside from the price is that it loads 3rd-party assets on all pages even if they don’t have any comments.
#Text=The Facebook comment is also a great option and FREE.
#Text=It’s fantastic for getting tons of engagement and doesn’t show all comments at once (like Disqus).
#Text=It also racks up your Facebook share count number with each comment.
#Text=I only don’t like it because of the external loads.
#Text=Please, no Thrive Comments!
#Text=If you’re attracted to Disqus you might consider Commento but beware (you can’t migrate there natively from WordPress, yet…you have to pass through Disqus first).
#Text=92.
#Text=Deferring chatboxes (BEG, MED)
#Text=Many of you have slow page loads because of your (sales/support) chatboxes.
#Text=These aren’t related to your page design and shouldn’t get in the way.
#Text=Luckily, they’re easy to deal with.
#Text=Manually put the code in the footer.Defer JS – most cache plugins have this.Lazy load JS – Swift cache has this.
#Text=It’s fantastic.
#Text=93.
#Text=Speeding up email forms (INT, MED)
#Text=If you’ve got newsletter forms on your site to integrate with email marketing services (Mailchimp, MailerLite, etc), you’ll notice many of them load annoying 3rd-party scripts.
#Text=Some of these JS are for form security (preventing spam registrations), others are for other functions (like conversions).
#Text=Here are my tactics for dealing with them:
#Text=Don’t load email forms globally – don’t put them on every page!
#Text=I also hate them from a UX point of view (annoying users).
#Text=You can try just a “SIGN UP” button or link that redirects them to the newsletter page.

#Text=But yeah, that might affect your conversions and take them off the page.Use a form that doesn’t need external JS – some email services can do it.Load the form locally – but risky if it stops working one day!
#Text=Always manual embed – instead of automated through a plugin.
#Text=Ultimately, the service you pick will determine your options.
#Text=Some have JS-free options.
#Text=Others require JS no matter what.
#Text=94.
#Text=DNS Prefetch (INT, LOW)
#Text=Enable DNS prefetch by putting prefetch tags in your header.Or do it through your cache plugin.But please don’t install a performance plugin just for DNS prefetch.
#Text=A great tactic for speeding up external asset calls is to speed up their DNS wait times.
#Text=What slows down external assets is usually the network latency time to send a request to the 3rd-party server.
#Text=The file itself may be very small but the network time is what delays it.
#Text=By putting a DNS prefetch to external domains, your server makes the HTTP request earlier during the site load so the asset loads quicker when it’s needed.
#Text=Common URLs to prefetch:
#Text=Google fontsFacebook PixelOther social media networksChat scripts?
#Text=Conversion scripts?
#Text=Don’t know which URLs to prefetch?

#Text=Run a Pingdom speed test – and look at the domains listed.Or to get a full list – open up your browser’s Developer Tools > Sources (tab).You should browse several pages of your site to make sure you get all the common ones.Only prefetch the root domain/subdomain, not the entire URL.Also not necessary to preload all domains that you see.Be careful of ad-related domains that change on each page load.
#Text=(You shouldn’t prefetch these.)
#Text=95.
#Text=DNS preconnect (INT, LOW)
#Text=“Preconnect” is the lesser known brother to “prefetch”.
#Text=Arghhh, here’s comes an explanation:
#Text=preload – preloads assets for the current page.prefetch – preloads only the DNS call for the next page.preconnect – preloads the DNS call, TLS negotiation and TCP handshake…for the next page.

#Text=Preloading shouldn’t be used as it can eat a lot of resources and doesn’t make sense for WordPress unless you know exactly why some assets need to be loaded first (and can’t be prioritized in other ways).
#Text=Prefetch aka “DNS prefetch” is a safe low-resource way to preload calls, and heavily supported by browsers.
#Text=It conveniently establishes the DNS connection so assets coming from external domains will be downloaded quicker when requested.
#Text=Preconnect is like prefetch but does a little more (it establishes the TLS/TCP connection as well as the DNS) but isn’t as popular for several reasons.
#Text=One is because it wasn’t supported by as many browsers.
#Text=Another is because there’s a simultaneous connection limit in most browsers.
#Text=Ultimately, you have to decide what’s most important to preconnect, and the rest can be
#Text=prefetched.
#Text=Limit preconnect only to priority connections.Some sites do preconnect before prefetch.
#Text=Others do opposite but also prefetch the preconnect-ed ones.
#Text=Some also put prefetch in the same tag as the preconnects.I probably wouldn’t preconnect more than 4 domains.
#Text=Prefetch, you can do as many as you want.I personally don’t bother with preconnect.
#Text=Only some very big sites do.
#Text=The preconnect and dns-prefetch resource hints – Web Platform NewsDNS-Prefetch and Preconnect – One, or Both?
#Text=Fallback?
#Text=– Stack OverflowUsing Preload and Prefetch in Your HTML to Load Assets – Alligator.io
#Text=96.
#Text=Cloudflare apps (INT, MED)
#Text=It’s relatively new and I haven’t played much with it.
#Text=But it looks extremely promising!
#Text=The new Cloudflare Apps allows developers to create applications and services that integrate at the EDGE-level (aka “DNS”) rather than at the SOFTWARE-level (aka WordPress, php).
#Text=This opens up a wide range of possibilities because:
#Text=The applications/scripts are loaded from Cloudflare servers!
#Text=(Making them faster.)It’s less work for developers.
#Text=Their app can be applied to any website (not limited to any CMS, or WordPress).
#Text=Check it out yourself!
#Text=https://www.cloudflare.com/apps/
#Text=See which apps you use are on there.Tawk.to, Facebook (chat/like/comments), social feeds, chat boxes, forms, support, media, etc.There are so many!!!
#Text=Really incredible stuff as they don’t load anything from your server!
#Text=No plugins to install or configure.
#Text=Just enable from your Cloudflare account.
#Text=Amazing!
#Text=(This could completely change the game not only for how future applications and services are integrated with websites, but make slow websites a thing of the past.)
#Text=9.
#Text=Security optimization
#Text=Hacking and cyber attacks can cause massive server performance problems if not outright interruptions.
#Text=Many people have no idea how often servers get attacked because they never see the logs.
#Text=I can assure you every server will get attacked several thousand times (sometimes in one hour) every month.
#Text=Your site might even be attacked right now but you just don’t know it.
#Text=Securing against these attacks requires a delicate balance.
#Text=You don’t want a server that lets hackers freely bombard your ports and resources.
#Text=But you also don’t want a server that’s too secure and excessively auditing all traffic that it slows your users or worse (it blocks legitimate users).
#Text=Of the recommendations below, follow the ones you have access to.
#Text=Servers hosting only you and/or few tenants:

#Text=Easier to secure because there are fewer sites to invite hacking and you can safely disable many ports without affecting your sites.Harder to secure if you’re managing it yourself and lack experience.
#Text=Servers hosting many tenants:
#Text=Easier to secure if there’s admins already monitoring the server.
#Text=Many common attacks already secured against.Harder to secure if many services need to be open for different client use cases.
#Text=Therefore, more sites and open services to invite hackers.
#Text=You should read my guide on How to HARDEN a Linux web server.
#Text=97.
#Text=Shutdown unnecessary server services (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=You can think of unused services as unused phones or email accounts.
#Text=They sit around eating up resources (MEMORY) and take up your time with unwanted connections (SPAM, HACKERS).
#Text=Whatever you’re not using, disable it from your server!
#Text=DNS – disable if using external DNS server.
#Text=(Cloudflare, DNSME, etc.)Email – disable if using 3rd-party email.
#Text=(G-Suite, MXroute, etc.)FTP/SFTP – disable if not using.Other proxies – like Varnish.
#Text=Many of these services are enabled by default with your server stack or control panel.
#Text=You can read their documentation to get a list.
#Text=For services that need to be running, you can limit their exposure to bad traffic using firewalls.
#Text=98.
#Text=Server firewall configuration (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Most default firewall configurations are set too lax to avoid causing issues.
#Text=You should jump in there and block off as much as possible.
#Text=Some example logic below:
#Text=Ports used by specific people (SSH, FTP) – only you or a few others.
#Text=Do an IP whitelist and block the rest.
#Text=Ports used by certain country (POP3, IMAP, FTP) – if some services are only used from within one country, you can block all other countries.
#Text=Be careful though as someone traveling will lose access!
#Text=Ports attacked only by certain country – if you have many attacks coming from certain countries or regions, you can ban by country or entire IP ranges.
#Text=There are many server firewalls out there.
#Text=Each with their own pros and cons and recommended for different uses cases.
#Text=You can read up online how others use and configure them.
#Text=It’s easiest to start with the default one that comes with your stack.
#Text=99.
#Text=Server brute force protection (ADV, HIGH)
#Text=Brute-force protection is like a smart firewall.
#Text=It leaves services and ports open but automatically bans the obvious offenders.
#Text=It automatically bans anyone putting in the wrong authentication, or using blacklisted generic user-names, etc.
#Text=They’re easy to set and very powerful.
#Text=Just be careful that they don’t block legitimate users/traffic.
#Text=You can see what brute-force or DDOS protection came with your server and enable it.
#Text=Maybe don’t set it so strict if you have many users on this server.
#Text=100.
#Text=Brute-force protection on wp-login.php (BEG, HIGH)
#Text=The WordPress admin login page is often bombarded by bots trying random user-names and passwords to get through.
#Text=While they might not get in, their constant attempts eat up lots of resources.
#Text=There are several ways to prevent them, each with their pros and cons.
#Text=Server-level brute force protection – easy and efficient but can lockout legitimate users on busy servers with sites using Cloudflare.
#Text=Problem is brute-force lockouts block by IP and visitors coming in through Cloudflare all share the same (proxy) IP.
#Text=Sure, you can configure to pass true client IP through Cloudflare headers but this slows down page load!
#Text=Application-level brute force protection – many WordPress security plugins can do this.
#Text=They secure the login page by banning users with bad credentials.Some plugins hide the login page – moving it to a different URL.

#Text=Just make sure the standard login URL is either blocked or cached to prevent visits on it from using resources.Other plugins protect the login form by putting a captcha and banning certain robots, crawlers, devices.
#Text=This can work well but might annoy or false-flag legitimate users.
#Text=Only server I know with native brute-force protection on wp-login.php is LiteSpeed.
#Text=All other servers (Apache & NGINX) will have to enable it with either a security plugin or http auth.
#Text=101.
#Text=HTTP authentication (BEG, MED)
#Text=Do you have specific pages being bombarded and no convenient way of blocking access to them?
#Text=HTTP AUTH is a quick-and-dirty way of locking out all users.
#Text=Only problem is it’s a slight hassle for legitimate users.
#Text=Most guides show you how to protect the wp-admin directory but you can protect other frequently-visited ones as well.
#Text=Setup HTTP AUTH on Apache/LiteSpeedSetup HTTP AUTH on NGINXHandy HTTP AUTH passwords generator.
#Text=102.
#Text=Disable XML-RPC protocol (BEG, MED)
#Text=The XML-RPC protocol allows external apps (like mobile apps), to log into your WordPress and edit content or view WooCommerce sales.
#Text=Unfortunately, it’s often exploited by hackers and bots brute-forcing their way into your site.

#Text=If you don’t use it, disabling XML-RPC prevents server slowdowns caused by the thousands of XML-RPC hack requests.If you need to leave it on, you can whitelist your IP’s (and also for Jetpack, if you use it).
#Text=103.
#Text=Security plugin configuration (BEG-INT, MED)
#Text=If you don’t have access to your server, you can use security plugins.

#Text=Yes, security is more efficiently run at the server level (closer to raw computing power) than at the application level (slower PHP processing)…but sometimes, it’s hard to set global security rules when you have many clients/sites and each one needs something different.
#Text=Nonetheless a software-level security plugin like WordFence is still a useful option to block attacks that the server doesn’t, and/or prevent hacked sites from doing more damage.
#Text=My favorite WordPress security plugin is WordFence.Most important feature of security plugins IMO is malware scanning.
#Text=Scan manually or schedule during low-traffic hours.

#Text=This feature doesn’t necessarily improve website speed, it detects system exploits and prevents them from using up resources (hosting spam sites or attacking other servers).The firewall features on security plugins probably aren’t needed if you have a server firewall already.
#Text=Firewalls activated at the PHP level slow all incoming requests.
#Text=The performance problem with security plugins is due to A) over-aggressively filtering all incoming traffic, and B) scanning too often.
#Text=Both eat up many resources especially on large sites with many pages and visitors.
#Text=I suggest not using software firewall, and also to set your malware scans to a slower speed.
#Text=104.
#Text=DNS edge-level security configuration (BEG, MED)
#Text=Remember how I said that security is more efficiently done at the server level than at the application level?
#Text=Well doing it at the edge level (DNS-level) can be even more efficient than at your server level since it’s using someone else’s servers.
#Text=There are some performance implications between dealing with security at the edge VS on your server.
#Text=You can decide what works best for your use case.
#Text=Dealing with security on your server can be more convenient since you have more control.
#Text=You can optimize for your specific use.

#Text=Only downside is it uses your server resources and also that you need admin skills.Dealing with security via another server (like DNS proxy, Cloudflare) or security service (Sucuri) saves your server precious resources but might add slight load delay issues since visitors are passing through an extra proxy before reaching your web-server.
#Text=The weaker your server and server-admin skills, the more likely a security service is more efficient at blocking DDOS requests.
#Text=Then again, for a smaller site you might not have so much security problems.
#Text=Whatever you do, don’t try to put overly-aggressive DDOS security at both levels (DNS & server).
#Text=This can cause false-positives where legit visitors are blocked because all visitors (good and bad) share the same IP when coming through a proxy.
#Text=Most people don’t have to worry about DDOS attacks, ok?

#Text=Most lower-level DDOS attacks are easily handled by your server.The highest-level DDOS attacks are the ones that overwhelm servers (even with good security) but they cost money and concentrated effort from hackers.

#Text=Unless someone is specifically targeting you, you don’t have to worry about them.Easiest way to deal with high-level DDOS attacks is to immediately sign up with a dedicated security company like Sucuri (when it happens).I don’t recommend paying for fancy security services that you mostly won’t need.
#Text=105.
#Text=HTTPS and HTTPS redirect
#Text=(BEG, LOW)
#Text=You should absolutely be using HTTPS.

#Text=(It’s the only way to get the benefits of HTTP/2 protocol.)Put 301 HTTPS redirects on your server so visitors are quickly redirected to the proper HTTPS protocol and correct domain version of your site (with or without “www”).
#Text=Without these server redirects, WordPress can still do it but it takes a little longer.
#Text=Also, don’t forget to make sure all your internal urls are using HTTPS (follow step 3).
#Text=Don’t rely on SSL plugins (unnecessary) or WordPress (slow) to redirect you.
#Text=Set the redirects from the server!
#Text=Bonus tip: if using Cloudflare, set a page rule to do your HTTPS 301 redirects from there as well.
#Text=(Even faster than from local server!)
#Text=106.
#Text=Web Application Firewalls, aka “WAF” (INT, MED)
#Text=WAF are enabled through your server security stack.The easiest way to block bots without any performance loss is manually through htaccess or global server config.
#Text=But this can be too much manual work when managing many sites.

#Text=Therefore it’s safer to have WAF for them.If you’re using ModSecurity, check out these ModSecurity performance tips from Trustwave and Packt.You may also enable a high-performance WAF through Cloudflare security rules, or 3rd-party paid security services…like Sucuri.
#Text=Most people don’t know the difference between network firewall and web application firewall (WAF).
#Text=Network firewall is for opening and closing ports.
#Text=WAF is for blocking bots through open ports.
#Text=You have to be careful with WAF security because it can slow down your server since it checks all incoming traffic (regardless of good or bad).
#Text=Due to performance reasons, I mostly avoid WAF if I can but my style of server management might not be feasible for others.
#Text=10.
#Text=Bad optimization (tactics)
#Text=All the unnecessary, illogical or outdated optimization advice passed around on the internet.
#Text=Listed here (along with my thoughts) in case you were curious.
#Text=Some sites are slow because of their users!
#Text=Most of these tactics are bad because:
#Text=They don’t fix the root problem.They don’t increase speed.

#Text=Some make it worse.They are outdated/irrelevant for today’s technology.Can break your website design or functions.Increase your server load.Make nearly unnoticeable benefit if any at all.Only work in limited scenarios.Only give you better page scores, but make the user experience worse.Their benefits don’t outweigh the disadvantages.
#Text=Bad webhosting optimizations:
#Text=107.
#Text=Horizontal-scaling (adding more servers).
#Text=Scaling will never be faster than running all services locally (off one machine).
#Text=Chaining servers together means your data has more proxies to jump through.Horizontal-scaling is meant for preventing high-traffic from slowing down your base speed.
#Text=It can’t speed up a low-traffic environment.The only scaling that increases baseline performance is vertical scaling i.e.
#Text=“upgrading server resources” like CPU, memory, disks, etc.
#Text=108.
#Text=Buying an expensive server.
#Text=This is a bandaid way of fixing a slow setup.
#Text=The extra money you spend on hosting could easily pay for better recoding.If your site has little traffic yet needs a $300/month server to be tolerable, just fix the code!
#Text=Expensive servers are noticeably faster for dynamic load only (admin pages, checkouts).
#Text=If your site is cached effectively, it makes no difference.
#Text=109.
#Text=Optimizing for speed tests and page scores.
#Text=Did you know that optimizing for high page scores can sometimes give you a slower site?
#Text=(It’s true!)
#Text=Why Google Pagespeed, Pingdom, and GTmetrix scores don’t matterHow to optimize for Google Pagespeed, Pingdom, and GTmetrix (for the people who insist)
#Text=110.
#Text=Deploying caging tactics for low-tenant servers.

#Text=Many people read random guides and tactics (like installing CloudLinux/CageFS) for servers and think it actually helps them.Most of those guides were written for high-tenant busy dedicated servers.
#Text=And not relevant to this new age of affordable VPS with only a few sites.Caging tactics will slow down your sites because they limit resources.
#Text=Bad theme optimizations:
#Text=111.
#Text=Using overly minimal themes.
#Text=If your theme is so empty that you have to load bloated pagebuilders and extra plugins to get the desired look, you might be defeating the purpose of a lightweight theme in the first place!
#Text=Maybe consider a nice child theme or prebuilt site design for Genesis or GeneratePress.Maybe consider Artisan Themes.
#Text=112.
#Text=Switching to static CMS (instead of WordPress).
#Text=Dumb move.

#Text=(WordPress vs Static CMS)Static CMS are fast because they’re simpler.They can’t do all the fancy designs and functions that WordPress can.Switching to static CMS actually requires more development skills!
#Text=Bad plugin optimizations:
#Text=113.
#Text=Installing multiple performance plugins.
#Text=The only one you need is a cache plugin.Do not install multiple performance plugins!
#Text=(Browser cache, disable wp-embeds, CSS combine, lazy load, etc.)Don’t install “booster” plugins for other plugins, either.
#Text=They’re likely using autoloads (memory) to speed it up…but that only speeds up the specific plugin at the expense of your entire site load.
#Text=114.
#Text=Using (conditional load) plugin organizers.
#Text=If you have to tell plugins not to load on pages where they aren’t used, it’s probably not a good plugin in the first place.It’s best if you just remove or replace those plugins.
#Text=Bad image optimizations:
#Text=115.
#Text=Lazy loading images.

#Text=Yes, I’m aware my belief goes against what many people think.I don’t care, I hate lazy load.Sure, it gets better page scores but slows down the user experience.Sites always look better with it off!
#Text=116.
#Text=Over-compressing images.
#Text=Don’t over-do it to the point that they look ugly.Maybe make them smaller?
#Text=Or if you lower their quality, darken them and put text on top so it’s less noticeable.
#Text=117.
#Text=Excessive inline SVG’s.
#Text=It’s fine if you have like 1 or 2.
#Text=Any more than that and you’re just making your HTML bigger.SVG’s are almost always not critical items.AND they’re usually loaded on every page.
#Text=Let them be separated requests from the HTML so they can be browser cached.If you really want lighter weight, create a custom icon font!
#Text=118.
#Text=Leaving image compression backups on the server.
#Text=If using image compression plugins, delete their backups off your server to keep it light.If you want to keep the originals, download them to your computer.
#Text=119.
#Text=Media cloud hosting service.
#Text=Did some fancy company convince you to offload your images to S3?
#Text=And use their fancy CDN service to “load your images faster?”
#Text=I can assure you it’s a dumb idea.

#Text=Image assets will most likely load faster from your origin server than through a slow external storage server like S3.S3 is basically only a last-ditch effort if you run out of space on your server and don’t want to pay for an expensive server (with fast disks) elsewhere.
#Text=Let me repeat, S3 is slow storage.And it’s because that S3 is slow that those media-cloud plugins and services feel the need to add a CDN to it.
#Text=Don’t let them fool you.
#Text=Loading images from a slow external storage through a CDN proxy is going to be slower than loading off your origin server.If you can, load from your local server.

#Text=And if needed, use a CDN with your local server.The only time this external storage & CDN method is ever useful is if you have heavier video files or so many images, or you want to save money, or you have so much traffic that your CDN is always warm.
#Text=I would also add that if you’re going the external storage route, you should use a more proactive push-CDN than a pull-CDN.
#Text=Bad caching optimizations.
#Text=120.
#Text=Enabling every feature on cache plugins.
#Text=Don’t be the idiot breaking their site with cache plugins.Don’t enable separate mobile caching or AMP if you don’t have it!

#Text=Don’t cache private or logged-in users unless you have to.Don’t cache WooCommerce cart sessions (it’s almost never needed).If you don’t understand a feature, check the documentation or ask for help.Use only what you need.
#Text=Less is more!
#Text=121.
#Text=Enabling object caching when you don’t need it.

#Text=It’s only meant for dynamic pages.If all pages are static, using object caching can slow it down.Unnecessary object caching can also eat up memory, improperly configured object caching can serve old data.
#Text=122.
#Text=Browser caching for too long.

#Text=Browser caching is usually intended for static assets that rarely change (images, CSS, JS).Safe settings can be 1-7 days so they’re not downloaded again if the same browsers revisits within that time period.Aggressive settings can be up to 30 days or even 1 year.The problem is if you change the images or CSS within that time period, some users will see the old version.
#Text=123.
#Text=Preloading pages.
#Text=Clever tactic of preloading pages before you click on them!
#Text=(Then they appear instantly when clicked.)Some will preload all available links.

#Text=Others guess or preload only what you hover your mouse over.There are many technical implications regarding preloading…such as extra server requests (for items not even clicked), screwing with conversion/affiliate tracking, accidental self-DDOS, can even break page design or functions because of CSS/JS loaded at unexpected times.My biggest detraction is that they try to speed up sites by using extra server load on a server that wasn’t fast enough in the first place.
#Text=Sure, it can work on a slow server or bloated site if it doesn’t get much traffic.
#Text=Anyway, be careful when you use it!
#Text=Quicklink vs Instant.page vs Flying Pages – Why I built Flying Pages (WP Speed Matters) – great guide comparing preload plugins by Gijo Varghese.
#Text=124.
#Text=Static WordPress plugins/services.

#Text=I think these are more complicated (manual) ways of using cache.But can be useful for the power user who knows what he’s doing.For everyone else, you’re likely to have more troubles from using them.Want to try?
#Text=See for yourself…WP2Static and Shifter.
#Text=Bad asset load optimizations.
#Text=125.
#Text=Combining CSS/JS assets.
#Text=I hate combining CSS/JS.Can break site designs, delay initial response, increase server load, or even slow down your sites.
#Text=The benefits aren’t even noticeable (except for silly page tests).The benefits are better on big bloated sites, but so are the drawbacks.
#Text=Just test with it on vs off.
#Text=(And test with your eyes, not via page tests.)
#Text=126.
#Text=Generate Critical CSS.

#Text=Unless your site actually needs it AND you’re carefully generating the critical CSS, there won’t be much benefit.Often slows down your site load, break styling, or create FOIT/FOUT issues.The only effective way to generate Critical CSS is to do it manually.

#Text=But most people don’t have that skill and do it via automated plugin (which often includes unnecessary styles and misses necessary ones).Totally unnecessary for already lean sites.My full rant against critical CSS.
#Text=Looking for tools that can generate critical CSS?
#Text=Try Paul Kinlan’s bookmarklet for Google Chrome.Google “critical CSS generator”.
#Text=What’s the problem if you don’t generate critical CSS perfectly?

#Text=A) your site doesn’t look right, suffers FOUC for a little bit and then finally loads everything.B) doesn’t look right periodC) looks right but still loads too many unnecessary styles.D) worst case scenario, you get some combo of multiple above.
#Text=127.
#Text=Inlining CSS.
#Text=Mostly dumb idea.Intended only for page-specific CSS, like simple 1-liners that don’t need to be an extra HTTP request.Not intended for outputting entire CSS into the HTML.

#Text=This adds extra load to each page that could have been globally cached.Will actually slow down subsequent visits since that CSS has to be re-parsed again and probably not even cached.This tactic is only for ultra-light pages with nearly zero styling.
#Text=It’s terrible for speeding up bloated pages.
#Text=128.
#Text=Removing query strings for CSS/JS assts.
#Text=Maybe some page test told you to do this.But then what happens when you do it?
#Text=CSS changes take forever to show on browsers that already saw your site (since they have the old version cached).Good job, genius.

#Text=Now you’re stuck with cache-busting issues.This tactic is already outdated since most browsers and services (like CDN) can effectively cache assets with query strings.If you still insist on it, at least wait until you’re absolutely done with the site design.
#Text=Or else design changes will take longer to show.
#Text=129.
#Text=Defer CSS or JS.
#Text=Another potentially stupid idea.

#Text=(Usually done by users trying to avoid “render-blocking” warnings.)It can delay critical CSS/JS used at the top of your page (like for sliders or other content effects).If you’re deferring and delaying CSS/JS load for critical items, your page may get higher page scores but appear slower for visitors.FYI: some assets need to be render-blocking for a reason.
#Text=It’s because they control how the content looks.
#Text=For example…do you want your carousel images to load BEFORE the carousel?
#Text=Or do you want your text to load before the font?
#Text=NO!
#Text=…because it’ll look ugly or all jangled up!
#Text=130.
#Text=Cache-all using Cloudflare.
#Text=Many have tried, many have failed.Seems like an incredible trick until you realize some function broke.
#Text=I don’t recommend even trying this unless you have a simple site (that probably won’t need it anyway).Still want to try?
#Text=Caching WordPress Pages using Cloudflare Page Rules (WP Speed Matters) or the WP Cloudflare Super Page Cache plugin.
#Text=131.
#Text=Bad Cloudflare settings.
#Text=Rocket Loader – don’t enable this!
#Text=It breaks stuff.SSL/TLS on Full (strict) = don’t use this option as it makes your SSL handshake take longer.
#Text=Just use the default option!
#Text=It is fine and everything will look normal with the padlock.HSTS – leave this off!
#Text=It will prevent browsers from displaying your site if you ever have SSL problems.Cache entire page with page rules – already mentioned above.Just follow my Cloudflare settings guide, ok?
#Text=Bad external asset optimizations.
#Text=132.
#Text=Using CDN when you have a local business.
#Text=Completely unnecessary!
#Text=Doesn’t help speed at all!
#Text=PS: Cloudflare can be used without its CDN functions.
#Text=You can use it for DNS-only.
#Text=133.
#Text=Using Google AMP.

#Text=The main benefit of AMP in my opinion, is better syndication and SEO through Google’s search engine results.But I think it helps only for blog and news type of sites.AMP is not a good solution for speed.
#Text=It adds more complexity to your site and often breaks functions and design.
#Text=Worst of all, it doesn’t exactly help your speed and makes your site (and server) work harder to cache things.
#Text=Bad security optimizations.
#Text=134.
#Text=Excessive security deployed.
#Text=Aggressive firewall filtering – slows website visits.Security proxy (Sucuri) – slows visits.Brute-force security too strict – blocks legitimate users.
#Text=135.
#Text=Mixing server security with Cloudflare security.
#Text=Can block legitimate users since all users coming from Cloudflare share the same IP.
#Text=And if hackers trigger an IP ban, many legit users will be banned!
#Text=Be careful when using Cloudflare proxy with server security.Not usually an issue unless you’re on your own server.
#Text=To clarify: the issue is usually for logged-in users, regular public visitors usually won’t have any problems.
#Text=135.
#Text=HTTP Strict Transport Security aka “HSTS”.
#Text=Dumb idea!

#Text=Very little benefit but god forbid you have any random SSL issues (SSL didn’t renew or missing after migration), your site will not load.It’s a giant risk and always causes nightmares eventually.Don’t you ever turn this on!
#Text=I scream at all clients who do this.
#Text=What’s the secret to speeding up WordPress sites?
#Text=For me, it use to be finding endless tactics and places to optimize.
#Text=And it worked.
#Text=I was able to drop from 4 seconds to 1 second.
#Text=Then 1 second to 500ms.
#Text=Then 500ms to 380ms, then painstakingly chip off every 10-20ms.
#Text=Major gains at this point were only 50ms.
#Text=…but this isn’t how the real world works.
#Text=Ain’t nobody got that kind of time.
#Text=Ain’t nobody want to spend that kind of money.
#Text=Speed optimization for the real world requires intuition.
#Text=You have to be able to look at a site, smell it, and know right away what it needs.
#Text=So you don’t waste a bunch of hours on tactics that make no difference.
#Text=The problem with most speed optimization tactics and speed-up services:

#Text=They use a general formula that doesn’t work for every site.They do things the easy way, not the best way.They don’t account for the user’s workflow and content intervals.They don’t account for the type of webhosting (and it’s limitations).They don’t account for the user experience.They almost never do any manual optimizations.
#Text=They only strive for A+ page scores and lower total load times…which aren’t anywhere near as important as TTFB and content paint times.
#Text=Anyway, I hope this guide helps you.
#Text=Or at the very least, helps you find people who can care for your site as much as you do.
#Text=Speed optimization is a masterful art combining the skillsets of web developer, server admin, UI/UX designer, and website owner who’s actually owned a high-traffic website before.
